text: Welcome to Unit 1 of Intro to Agroecology. This unit's entitled, Current Non-Sustainable Agriculture Practices. What we'll be covering in this unit is what currently is happening and farming and why we need to make some changes as we go into the future and able to, in order to be able to feed the population of the world. Here is just a picture of way back when of what the farming practices were like. And basically the reason this picture is here to show you how they used to plow the land, and it was just all open all the time. You can see right now nothing's growing. This would be in a dormant time probably in the late fall, winter, or early spring before we planted. And it's just to show you that that's what they used to do. And we'll talk as we go on in this unit and discuss some of the changes we need to make. Some of the areas we're going to look at, we're going to look at the current practices that we currently do in agriculture. We're going to look at how we work the land that's the tillage practices that we use currently. And we'll talk a little bit about from the beginning when they started out with the prairies and made them into farmland to today and the differences in philosophies and why they did that. We're going to talk about synthetic fertilizers and why they have become an issue and why we need to change into organic fertilizers. We're going to talk a little bit about weed and pest control practices that are in use today that we use. And most of those are synthetic, not organic. And we'll talk about why we need to change those too. We'll also talk about a change that used to be all small family farms. And it's becoming more and more as time goes on, large corporations doing the farming and raising the animals. And we'll talk about why that's been good and bad. And then we'll talk about some of the limitations we have with our current practices as we go forward in the future and why we need to change in order to be able to feed everyone. The first area we'll talk about is the tillage practices that are in use today. Basically, when they had the native prairies, they called it busting the prairie, but you were actually taking a piece of equipment and making sure that it could dig into the land. And they used to do that every year. And we found out that in the practices of doing that, where we're losing a lot of soil because of erosion in the wintertime, because it was open, like that first picture we saw in this unit. We're going to look at some of the different pieces they've used or they're currently using. And we're going to talk a little bit about why did they change over the last 50 years into using new practices. One of the reasons they changed was because of the dust bowl they had that they found out that the reason they had the dust bowl was because we were plowing and we were leaving the fields open and prone to being able to have erosion. The wind was blowing the soil everywhere except where you wanted it to be. Then we're going to look also at some of the conservation things that they've come about probably starting in the late 60s, early 70s to today. And why are they practicing it? And why is the farm bureaus that are out there helping people, helping the current farmers, learn that they need to change what they're doing? And then up to the current where we're pretty much now most farmers are believing that no till is the way they should do versus breaking the prairie or using the plow all the time. There's a lot of farmers that don't even have plows anymore, but basically what the no till is is they've changed when they plant, they've added some equipment to it that makes them able to plant and open the ground a little bit, but we're doing it a lot less than what we did and it's actually saving the land that we have. Some of the current tillage methods that we have, there's cultivation and what cultivation is, is after the plants are planted they go in there and they try to control the weeds. So they can do that up to a certain point. It doesn't matter whether it's corn or soybeans, the two most common crops that are out there for most farmers. It's just a little, they call it a chisel plow, it's a V-shaped piece of equipment and what happens is it just goes between the rows of the crops whether it's corn or soybeans and it actually pulls the weeds out of the ground. You can only do that till it gets about a foot high, but then at that point the crop tends to crowd out the ability for the sun to get to the ground which is how seeds germinate for weeds and you don't have that problem anymore or certainly not as much. Plowing is the first time when you do it if you've never farmed land or if you had it, let's say impass your land or it was just fallow, which means you don't have any crops on it at all that you might have to work with a plow in order to be able to plant again. Disking is a practice that's not used as much anymore but basically it used to be used all the time in the 60s and 70s that they go in right before they planted. It's a round shaped saucer and there's a bunch of them hooked on, we'll have a picture of it later to see it and basically it would turn the ground a few inches in and provide for the ability to be able to plant easy. Minimum till was when you would do it not as often. They got to a point where they did not at the end of the year when they took the crops out. The crop residue was there. They used to always either come in and discot or they turn it with a plow for the winter time and then they come in and disc in the spring and you'd be able to plant and they'd have a smooth surface to plant on. Now what they do is they leave that residue. A lot of what they found out will go away in the winter time from the freeze saw cycles and then there's now no till when they started adding that extra it's just a little disc actually. It'll just open the soil enough to put the seed in the ground and that's what they call no till. So technically it is a little bit of tilling but it's not as much as it was when you used to do the disking. On this slide this just goes through the stuff I said about cultivation, plowing and disking. It talks a little bit more detail for the cultivation and removing those weeds and why does it create a better growing environment because if there's less competition for the plants the plants are going to do better. They're all competing for excuse me all the nutrients and water so the less plants that are there and the ones that you want that are there they're going to grow better for you. Plowing it'll dig down in 10 to 12 inches so you can see that digging down that far how you're opening up a big area when it turns over and you'll see a picture of it in a little bit that that's what allows for that erosion when the wind comes to have it blow around. Pretty much now it's only used when you're preparing a new field. Disking told you before it's a platter like device. It only goes in four to six inches and it really doesn't turn it like a plow it just kind of cuts it apart because of how the disc is and basically when there are some farmers that still do it they'll do it at the end of harvest to break apart the corn or soybean residue that's there and basically cornfields are what they use it in. The soybeans don't leave as much residue okay. Some farmers still use it for when they plant a new crop because that's what they've always done. We all get in habits. The minimum till is that disc in a field before you plant but you don't ever use plowing at all. And I would say most farmers are either in minimum till or no till. I'd say a vast majority probably 90 to 95 percent today across the U.S. No till is when they don't use the the disc or plow and they go ahead and harvest plant and harvest without doing that but once again the planter that they use has a little disc on that opens it up enough that you can plant the seed in the ground. Here's a picture of disking and you can see it's pretty it's not completely smooth but in the next picture you're going to see the reason you do this is it opens it up but what it also does is it also allows for seeds to come up for weeds which would allow more weeds to come up and that's part of the thing too when you do the no till you're not going to get as many weed seeds that are on top and weeds in any seed needs the sun to be able to germinate so you want to make sure you control that and that's one of the things they found out they have a lot less weeds. Not having as many weeds you'll also find out when we talk about fertilizers that that's better too because you're not putting as much synthetic things on the land which we found out isn't that good. Here you can see when they turn it that they have a this area right in here that I circled with my pointer that it's a little bit higher and that's the ridge it leaves there's one across the second one here how those are created is up here is where the disc are it's just a curved piece of metal that's about a foot and a half wide and that's what actually goes into the ground they have a hydraulic element and they are able to go into the ground that far the farmer can lift it by a control he has on his tractor. Talking about synthetic fertilizers. The synthetic fertilizers came about around the time that they ended the Second World War and it was basically because we were farming we weren't they needed to they always want to increase production and that was a way in which fertilizer of course we all use it on you know house plants we have like um miracle grow and it helps the plant grow it provides nutrients it needs specifically nitrogen that'll help that plant do better most farm crops nitrogen is um the fertilizer they want to put on there to make it grow better but one of the problems that they found out um that they didn't know right in the beginning was that those synthetic fertilizers don't make the soil vitality any better in other words the nutrients in the soil that stay there they found out that it uses it right away and then there's nothing there so basically the soil is getting worse and worse every year the other thing is in a normal soil there are micronutrients and micronutrients aren't in as large a supply as a macro nutrients that are out there and nitrogen happens to be one of the macronutrients but basically there are things that help a plant get stronger they help a plant flower better those types of things and there's things like boron that are some of the micronutrients but there's total of all nutrients there's 17 different ones and in a unit that's going to follow we'll get into all of the macro and micronutrients so that'll make a lot more sense to them also what happens is that by putting in the fertilizers and it's not a total result of that but because you aren't building the soil and the vitality isn't as good it's going to become more compressed over time because it's taking out some of those nutrients and it's going to not be real good for the soil um one of the other things they're found out is all the nitrogen we put on the um on the land when we're doing this there's times that a lot of that fertilizer will leach out that means it leaves it without doing the desired effect that you want with the fertilizer and basically what happens is it goes from the farm field into ditches then to streams then to rivers and it eventually gets down to the Gulf of Mexico and basically what happens on that is that's where all of the basically is killing the coral reefs and stuff and all the all the plants and animals that are at the end of the Gulf of Mexico and this happens all over the world it's just not in the Gulf of Mexico but basically what we're finding out is that we're really putting too much on because if it doesn't need it it just runs off the other thing is if you put it on at the wrong time if it rains sometimes rain will make it wash away if the water's you know running off the field real quickly here's an example of a farmer applying fertilizer and in this case he's applying nitrogen and specifically it's called anhydrous ammonia it's a it's a gaseous liquid gas that basically if you breathe that you would probably not be here anymore it's very dangerous but basically what you see and it's a good example here if you look at between this is an example of corn if you look between it there's a residue from the corn of last year one of the things that we'll we'll get into this in more detail as we go through the course but that's one of the problems they have that some of the crops we put in will put some nutrients back into the soil corn's not one of those it actually just takes nutrients especially nitrogen and that's what's making the vitality of the soils uh less and less all the time and we'll talk in ways we can make that better too here's an example of the prior slide showed you were just applying nitrogen you apply it everywhere okay it's really only needed where the plant is but there's not an effective way we can really do that without putting it on the whole field here is an example of it wouldn't so much be a farmer's not going to be out there doing this but it just shows you can use a selective weed killer even if you spray it on the whole field but what's good about this is it's only going to kill the uh intended plant you want so if you're out in a just say a grass yard um you can spray a weed killer a selective weed killer and it's not going to kill the grass it's just going to kill the weed that you want it's the same in a farm field they can put in selective herbicides they call it and it doesn't kill the plant it only kills the weeds that are there for synthetic fertilizers um in in some ways that it's it's become something especially with corn that if you don't use it you're not going to get the crop yield that you want and and one of the ways that they've made it they've used genetics to be able to produce corn that that will give you a yield that you like back in the 40s and 50s they used to get about 40 to 45 bushels of corn for an acre of land right now they're exceeding 300 bushels of corn per acre so you can see that they've really really increased the amount of yield that you can get which means you get more yield which means you get more money and everyone loves it part of the problem is is you needed a lot of nitrogen to do that and because you put more nitrogen there's more runoff so you have a big issue with that so that's some of the stuff that we're going to start talking about what can we do to become more sustainable which you'll see is a huge word as we go through this class um irrigation will also aggravate the problem we talked earlier when you get too much rain um you can have an issue with it but but with that is is it'll make it run off a little bit more you just have to be careful with that irrigation isn't in most farms it's usually only in vegetable farms um so if you're raising stuff like potatoes or pumpkins or you know peas or you know things you buy in the store like that as opposed to corn and um soybeans which are your byproducts used they create many different products but they you don't eat that corn directly um also irrigation aggravates a problem that it adds salt to the soil and too much salt is not good for soil either and it doesn't necessarily go away salt tends to stay it doesn't tend to um leave the area and that could be a problem and certainly is a problem in some of the areas that do irrigation um fertilizers are becoming tremendously expensive um they didn't used to be very expensive but even the fertilizer you buy for your yard you know 10 years ago used to be half the cost of what it is today so that's really made a big difference um and I talked earlier that the second to the last point there is corn would not produce what it does if you didn't fertilize it you'd probably get about a third the amount that you get currently so you get about a hundred bushels an acre as opposed to 300 and like we said when we do that it doesn't address that long-term vitality of the soil because what happens is it um just uses everything that's there and no nutrients are added and that's become a huge problem okay um also besides doing the nitrogen there's also chemicals that we use for pest and weed control um what they try to control when they use these chemicals are diseases that you might get on crops um insect infestations um and there's also the weeds you can get um what we do is one of the reasons we put the herbicides pesticides or fungicides on and herbicides are for the crops pesticides are things for like grasshoppers bull weevils that type of stuff the insects and fungicides are for the diseases um that you might get and it varies by crop and we'll talk a little bit about that as we get into the succeeding chapters of this course um some of the issues we have with the pest and weed control is that it is a synthetic item so it's not something that's natural and what we're finding is is not having natural things it isn't as good as we thought it was but what happens is over time we have found that the effectiveness of that chemical decreases in other words it isn't doing the same as it did because the insects and diseases are learning from they're going to get killed with let's say something like um DDT was a perfect example it killed everything but what we also found with that is over time that it affected the environment too so for the one one of the things that DDT affected tremendously were birds of prey so the big thing everyone will remember but basically it's hawks and eagles our birds of prey two of the big uh species that are out there and we almost lost all of the eagles because what happened is the shell of the egg got thinner and thinner and thinner because of DDT and basically when the mother or father eagles sat on the eggs they broke because they weighed too much um so now that we got rid of DDT in I believe it was the 70s um the eagles are making a comeback because everyone knows um but one of the issues with it is is that DDT was one of those chemicals that we thought you put it on and did its job and killed everything and then it went away uh guess what that's not true the DDT is still around and we haven't had it on in what 40 years they haven't applied any and it's still have a motor we don't see it in this picture but it actually swings around on a pendulum and it can go across that whole field and what you see here is those lines that are there where the tires going it actually uh ruin some of the crops but it still um does a good job watering and because you're watering it's in areas they probably don't have enough rain but things like corn and soybeans don't need to have rain generally the rain that you have in an area is enough but when you get crops like the veggies you really really need to have irrigation because they need more a lot more water okay and now we're going to start looking at um how changes have started happening over time um in terms of plants and animals is how we're going to look at this i'm going to change some kind of that they've had new hybrids and varieties of crops every year they come out with one of the ways we're getting higher and higher yields or the amount of crops we're pulling out of a field each year is they come out with new hybrids that will grow better in either a specific area a specific environment um or for a specific purpose um we've all heard the term GMO um how they've accomplished this is they've done the genetically modified organism is what GMO stands for and that's how they've come up with the new varieties basically when back in the olden days I guess I'll say they used to have what they called open pollinated crops and that was crops that basically if you took like say an ear of corn and saved the corn the next spring you could plant that corn and you get the same crop again well they did that you know 40 45 bushel an acre and that wasn't enough it wouldn't get anymore no matter what they did so they started geneticists started coming up with ways that they could produce more corn so you had larger cobs of corn ears of corn but when they did that what they're finding out now is that that GMO type stuff is starting to show up in the animals that are eating it it's showing up in the people that are eating the meat from the animals that are eating the GMO corn so we're not sure yet what that means totally if it's good or bad but we're beginning to believe that perhaps the GMO might not have been the right thing and we might have to look at coming up with new hybrids that maybe aren't as genetically altered or certainly do studies to find out whether or not it's affecting us in a good or a bad way or animals too. In terms of some of the stuff there are new cross breeds of animals and everyone's heard about the clone sheep and the clone cattle you know the the Betty the you know Barney whatever the names of these animals are England tends to be a place that has a lot of they've come up with a lot of cloned animals basically what they're trying to do when they do either a cloned animal or a cross breed is to pass on the desirable traits from one let's say a cow to the next one so in other words if there's qualities about that cow it has too much fat it it doesn't walk very well it has leaner meat all thing and it's it's I suppose like anything you you're going to have people that are on both sides of the fence but time will tell on that here's an example of one of the things that in the in the what used to always happen is here was an example where you have cattle feed lots okay you're in a pasture on individual farms and here's an example where there's not too many cattle here but in the cattle feed lots there are thousands and thousands of cows and it's that corporate farming and that it's in their opinion much cheaper to do that but we've had some issues with when we've done that when you look at the cattle feed lots you see how close they are together when the animals don't have as much room to roam one of the issues that they have is there's more pollution because they're generally not out on farms they're usually on the edge of towns and they have nowhere to take the animal waste and generally they just keep piling it up and piling it up whereas when it was on the old farm the individual family farms they used to take the animal waste and spread it on the fields and use that as fertilizer that nitrogen the other thing is when you have animals in a small area they're more prone to disease so therefore you had to start using antibiotics that they didn't used to have to use as much when they were out on the individual farms to try to control the different um diseases that they might get in terms of looking at these changes that we're seeing that single family farms are going away at an alarming rate and a lot of it used to be that the oldest son would always take over the family farm when dad decided to retire and dad and grandpa might help out on the farm but the son eventually had it the oldest one and that's generally what happened today it's segments.text: Welcome to Unit 1 of Intro to Agroecology.
This unit's entitled,
Current Non-Sustainable Agriculture Practices.
What we'll be covering in this unit is what currently is happening and farming
and why we need to make some changes as we go into the future and able to,
in order to be able to feed the population of the world.
Here is just a picture of way back when of what the farming practices were like.
And basically the reason this picture is here to show you how they used to plow the land,
and it was just all open all the time.
You can see right now nothing's growing.
This would be in a dormant time probably in the late fall, winter,
or early spring before we planted.
And it's just to show you that that's what they used to do.
And we'll talk as we go on in this unit and discuss some of the changes we need to make.
Some of the areas we're going to look at,
we're going to look at the current practices that we currently do in agriculture.
We're going to look at how we work the land that's the tillage practices that we use currently.
And we'll talk a little bit about from the beginning when they started out with the
prairies and made them into farmland to today and the differences in philosophies and why they did that.
We're going to talk about synthetic fertilizers and why they have become an issue and why we
need to change into organic fertilizers. We're going to talk a little bit about
weed and pest control practices that are in use today that we use.
And most of those are synthetic, not organic.
And we'll talk about why we need to change those too.
We'll also talk about a change that used to be all small family farms.
And it's becoming more and more as time goes on, large corporations doing the farming and
raising the animals. And we'll talk about why that's been good and bad.
And then we'll talk about some of the limitations we have with our current practices
as we go forward in the future and why we need to change in order to be able to feed everyone.
The first area we'll talk about is the tillage practices that are in use today.
Basically, when they had the native prairies, they called it busting the prairie, but you were
actually taking a piece of equipment and making sure that it could dig into the land.
And they used to do that every year. And we found out that in the practices of doing that,
where we're losing a lot of soil because of erosion in the wintertime, because it was open,
like that first picture we saw in this unit. We're going to look at some of the different
pieces they've used or they're currently using. And we're going to talk a little bit about why
did they change over the last 50 years into using new practices. One of the reasons they changed
was because of the dust bowl they had that they found out that the reason they had the dust bowl
was because we were plowing and we were leaving the fields open and prone to being able to
have erosion. The wind was blowing the soil everywhere except where you wanted it to be.
Then we're going to look also at some of the conservation things that they've
come about probably starting in the late 60s, early 70s to today. And why are they practicing it?
And why is the farm bureaus that are out there helping people, helping the current farmers,
learn that they need to change what they're doing? And then up to the current where we're pretty much
now most farmers are believing that no till is the way they should do versus breaking the prairie
or using the plow all the time. There's a lot of farmers that don't even have plows anymore,
but basically what the no till is is they've changed when they plant, they've added some
equipment to it that makes them able to plant and open the ground a little bit,
but we're doing it a lot less than what we did and it's actually saving the land that we have.
Some of the current tillage methods that we have, there's cultivation and what cultivation is,
is after the plants are planted they go in there and they try to control the weeds.
So they can do that up to a certain point. It doesn't matter whether it's corn or
soybeans, the two most common crops that are out there for most farmers.
It's just a little, they call it a chisel plow, it's a V-shaped piece of equipment
and what happens is it just goes between the rows of the crops whether it's corn or soybeans
and it actually pulls the weeds out of the ground. You can only do that till it gets about a foot
high, but then at that point the crop tends to crowd out the ability for the sun to get to
the ground which is how seeds germinate for weeds and you don't have that problem anymore or certainly
not as much. Plowing is the first time when you do it if you've never farmed land or if you had it,
let's say impass your land or it was just fallow, which means you don't have any crops on it at
all that you might have to work with a plow in order to be able to plant again. Disking is a
practice that's not used as much anymore but basically it used to be used all the time in the 60s and 70s

hooked on, we'll have a picture of it later to see it and basically it would turn the ground a few
inches in and provide for the ability to be able to plant easy. Minimum till was when you would do it

residue. A lot of what they found out will go away in the winter time from the freeze
saw cycles and then there's now no till when they started adding that extra it's just a little disc
actually. It'll just open the soil enough to put the seed in the ground and that's what they call
no till. So technically it is a little bit of tilling but it's not as much as it was when you
used to do the disking. On this slide this just goes through the stuff I said about cultivation,
